annotation.TEXT: The final dream sequence is actually an ideal spot to achieve a few specific feats (if you're playing the Steam version and are aiming to get them). The achievements "Boom!" and "Super Sphere" can easily be obtained here due to the sheer amount of enemies on-screen (kill 5 enemies at once with the War Horn, and kill 5 enemies within 5 seconds using any amount of Chaos Spheres respectively). Additionally, you'll get a ton of gems from doing this in the process.

I'm going to warn you right now: Much like that last segment, the fight with Polar Knight isn't pretty. Aside from sending out huge projectiles and having a fast dashing attack, he also has a desperation mode where he creates spikes in the floor. It also doesn't help that he's immune to the down-thrust (he'll block out any attempts you make with it, and will even counter attack if you do it too many times). In the very least though, you can still bounce off him to avoid his attacks despite it not damaging him.

It's worth noting that the statue itself can also block out most projectiles, making it an ideal shield for specifically placed enemies. You can also kill things with the statue as well, mainly by hitting it so that it sails into the enemies.

For as much as I find this level tiresome, I have to admit: These wolves are probably my favorite enemies in the game. I can't help but love the way they move, turn, and bounce around the stage (with very fluid animation at that). If you listen closely, you can also hear a very faint "howling" sound while they're around. This has to be the most unintentionally adorable enemy in the game (aside from maybe the Griffin, according to Jontron).

That music sheet up there is probably one of the most frustrating collectibles to reach in this game, if mostly due to the segment surrounding it. The whole thing focuses on the spikes/snow-pile gimmick seen before, only now you get to deal with several Frost Wizards and Ice Dragons in the process - the latter of which you actually need to keep alive in order to bounce up to the music sheet. The floating blocks aren't necessary to keep around, but they help out immensely with the process.

Chester will sell you the final relic of the game, the War Horn, for 4,000 gold in this stage. The War Horn acts somewhat like the full-screen enemy eraser of this game (although it doesn't actually extend to the whole screen, it does cover a very large radius around you). It deals quite a bit of damage, and it's useful for taking out hordes of enemies, but the main drawback is that it tends to eat up magic like nobody's business.

Not quite as amusing are the spear warriors. Aside from reminding me of something out of the funny pages, these guys are easily one of the most annoying enemies in this stage. They jump back whenever you get near them, and their spears actually seem to deal double damage for some reason (although it could be because of the "pointy object = bad" logic).

The snow piles are an interesting gimmick, but somewhat of a nerve-racking one. Touching them causes them to fall onto the spikes below, making them safe to traverse. Even though the snow itself falls faster than you, ensuring that you won't land on the spikes before it does (unless you don't jump at some of the ones higher up), I can't help but feel something might go wrong with these at the last moment.

Time to deal with the last main stage on this part of the map. Polar Knight's stage, in my opinion, is tied with Propeller Knight's in being the most difficult level in the game. Aside from being a long level in general, it has several new gimmicks and enemies that are more resilient and deal more damage. On top of this, almost every single breakable wall in this stage has a bomb in it.

The floating statues are the final main gimmick of this stage. Their gravity mechanics are pretty simple: standing on them causes them to drop down, and jumping off them causes them to float up. Thankfully, these things can't fall off the edge of the screen if you stand on them for too long (they'll simply hit the bottom and stay there), however you can potentially screw yourself over in a few spots if you let it drift too far upwards. Hitting them also causes them to spew out a rainbow trail, which you can use as a platform briefly until it fades away.
